s: ^Shells are not flat, have normal spire.
^Snails are coiled, small (less than 10mm), often black or dark brown and occur in large numbers.
^Mottled pattern visible through the shell. You might need good light to see this
^Shell halves are large (longer than 25 mm), dark, thick and usually not symmetrical.
^Shell halves are small (less than 25 mm); light coloured, relatively thin and symmetrical.
^Robust animals, freshwater crayfish or yabbies with obvious front pincers, movement walking or sometimes 'flips' of the tail that propel the animal backwards.
^Second leg with pincers and noticeably longer than others. Body translucent/opaque.
^Transparent (or at least translucent) front pairs of legs similar sized.
^Animals strongly flattened from the sides (like dogs and cats); often lying on their side or moving with their side flat against the substrate.
^Animals not flattened or flattened 'front to back' (like humans or cockroaches).
^Animal rests on its side, swims in swift bursts.
^Animal slow moving, walks, relatively robust looking animal, bovine.
^Small, pale (white to light brown or grey) crustacean, final segments as broad or broader than head, slow moving and slater-like.
^found on the surface of the water, or if underneath, it is covered in a silvery bubble of air.
^with no wing covers, possibly with wing buds
^Beetles swim rapidly in circular patterns on the water surface as well as below, shiny beetles with legs tucked neatly under body, often found in groups.
^Beetles move with all 3 or at least 2 pairs of legs. Legs move alternately.
^Beetles appear to swim smoothly with only the rear pair of legs, legs move in unison; motion is like breast stroke. Rear swimming legs held upwards when beetle rests.
^Always with a black head and a brown body; may screech when in net or tray. Distinctively 'lumpy' appearance; Rare.
^Often black but may be green or brown. Flat on the underside, sometimes with a bubble vest; head bent downwards; Common.
^Body segment associated with first pair of legs constricted to give the beetle a distinctly waisted look.
^Beetles with some form of colour pattern (variable patterns: mottled, brindled, stripes or patches.)
^Beetle with distinctive longitudinal stripes (like a pin-stripe).
^Beetle with dark patch in middle of head, body pale underneath.
^Beetle with light patch in middle of head, body dark underneath.
^Beetle with dark undersides. Never larger than 20mm.
^Beetle with orange undersides. Often larger than 20mm.
^Small to tiny beetles with well-developed claws, usually black, sometimes dark brown or red, with a shiny plastron or bubble vest; slow moving, sometimes hang motionless mid-water.
^Not as above, may crawl on the underside of the water surface.
^Small to tiny, elongate, often metallic beetles. Rare
^Larger dull coloured beetles sometimes with prominent yellow egg sac.
^Short bodied bugs that move quickly on the water surface.
^Elongate bugs with antennae at the very tip of the head. Walk slowly on water surface.
^Bugs with very long hind and middle legs. Move with a skating/sculling motion.
^Small to tiny bugs with shorter legs, running on the water surface.
^Ugly dark brown bugs with wide heads and a warty appearance. Pointed, grasping front legs. Semi-aquatic.
^Large (>20mm), elongate bugs with front legs for grabbing prey. Body stick or leaf like. Long legs. Long breathing tube at hind end.
^Long, thin, skinny bug, pale coloured. Looks like a stick or a piece of sedge.
^Long flattened bug, dark or black. Looks like a leaf.
^Bugs swim upside down, with legs uppermost, dark on upper surface, lighter coloured underneath.
^Bugs swim the right way up, with legs beneath them, wings on the upper surface if present.
^Tiny orange bugs with a highly convex humped back. No prominent swimming legs. Look a bit like a tiny, mobile jelly bean.
^Elongate bugs with two prominent, narrow swimming legs. Swim with a jerky motion. Very active. Obviously dark on one side (top) and light on the other (underneath).
^Robust, chunky, fast moving. Either at water surface or holding onto something. Triangular when viewed from above (animal on left of image).
^Slender, relaxed, unhurried movement. Able to stay still mid-water (thanks to buoyancy regulation). Thinner and parallel sided when viewed from above (animal on right of image).
^Larger 10-30mm bugs. Front legs pointed for piercing prey. Do not flick swimming legs when at rest.

^Small (<10mm) active bugs with two broad paddle like swimming legs which they flick back and forth when at rest. Streamlined body, blunt head. An air bubble may be visible under the body. May make buzzing or squeaking sounds in the tray.
^Medium sized bugs (10-15mm) with broad heads and light/dark checks (taxi stripes) along their sides.
^Larger bugs (up to 30mm) without checks. Flattened body, narrower heads.
^Head with 'nostrils' (Ocelli, they are more like eyes - see photo). Usually distinctly orange or yellow coloured head and underneath.
^Segment after the head (pronotum) with distinctive stripes or bands (see photo) you need a hand lens to see this.
^Small boatmen (<4mm), mottled or brindle wing covers (see photo). By far the commonest corixid.
^Large boatmen (>4mm) brown /yellow /grey, markings are not distinctive, looks a lot like television static (pre-digital telly). Unlike all of the above. Rare.
^with a case. Sometimes the case may be lost. Look for small, terminal, lateral hooks on the abdomen or ventral pro-legs on the abdomen.
^long legs,case never with coarse vegetation badly attached lengthways
^short, stumpy legs, case with coarse vegetation badly attached lengthways
^Caddis living in a portable case. Most crawl slowly, some swim by head-thrashing or arm-waving; if out of case, body blunt ending with tiny prolegs and hooks.
^Free-living caddis, body, long abdominal pro-legs with prominent claws.
^Tiny larvae <5mm long. Abdomen yellow, swollen, thicker than thorax. Purse shaped case of translucent silk, sometimes with sand or algae. Slow moving, hard to see.
^Fang-shaped case made from fine particles, sometimes with a groove. Hind legs curved like talons, head pointy, all body segments covered in hairs.
^Case made from plant material or silk secretion but may incorporate some mineral particles.
^Case like a messy ‘sand igloo’. Larvae fall out easily. Slow moving.
^Case not like a messy sand igloo.
^Case appears round but is actually coiled like a snail shell. Active but slow moving.
^Case triangular, often with larger particles down each side. Eyes of larvae protrude when viewed from above.
^Case tubular, legs sharp, for grabbing prey. Fast deliberate movement.
^Case made from flat pieces of leaf, giving it a flat appearance overall.
^Case made from all sorts, including: silk secretion, sticks, or other plant material and sometimes sand (never leaf plates by themselves). Case not flat.
^Case built from 2 flat pieces of leaf, the dorsal piece is slightly larger forming a 'veranda'.
^Case built from many round, shingle-like bits of leaf, in two distinct rows.
^Case built from a messy assortment of leaf plates, but still flat. Sometimes tapered quite severely.
^Larvae with short legs, head compact, bullet like. Case often made with rings of different colours, sometimes with sand or may look like orange plastic. Slow moving, never swimming.
^Larvae with long legs; may swim by thrashing their head about. Case variable.
^Case constructed from a single stick or piece of aquatic plant.
^Case constructed like a log cabin, square in cross section (see photo).
^Case with sand or fine gravel at the opening (front) and the rest of the case made from pieces of vegetation.
^Case made from a variety of materials, may be arranged spirally (but not always). When disturbed animal flails its body in a head-banging motion.
^Not as above. Generally a mix of caddis with long hind legs and mixed messy cases
^All three thoracic segments hard or sclerotised, they appear darker or different in colour to the soft abdomen.
^Abdominal gills present (hairy chest), slow moving. May undulate abdomen to ventilate gills. To 15mm.
^Abdominal gills absent, often with a pattern on the head like a bandits mask.
^Larvae often green when alive. Forelegs modified into a pincer, or broad with a large spine. Larvae hunt from side to side with the forelegs.
^Larvae without pincers, body not green. Often pale, head brown or yellow. Don't tend to hunt actively.
^with wingbuds and well developed compound eyes
^Slender larvae, with 3 terminal gills. Swim by undulating (snake-like).
^Robust larvae, without terminal gills. Swim by jetting water out of their bums.
^Leaf-like terminal gills held flat and fanned out horizontally.
^Gills equal in length or longer than last 3 abdominal segments.
^Gills divided into two parts by constriction.
^Medium sized nymphs with club or sausage shaped antennae. Sluggish, often green or brown. No obvious spines on the edges of abdominal segments.
^Fat, round ended body and long legs make them look spider-like. Mouthparts form a ladle-shaped mask in front of face.
^Relatively elongate body, NOT spider-like. Mouthparts flat, folded under 'chin'
^Dark mottled nymphs usually with large spines on the edges of the abdominal segments. Central bum-spine pointed.
^Green or brown nymphs. Central bum-spine with a cut-off end. This can be seen even on small nymphs.
^mouthparts short and curved or too small to see
^animals with a single row of projections along the sides of the abdomen
^animals without a single row of projections (may have a mess of gills)
^animals with robust posterior prolegs (like a pair of hooks on short prolegs at the end of the abdomen)
^7 or 8 abdominal projections (dangly bits), found in rivers
^9 or 10 abdominal projections (dangly bits), found in pools and wetlands
^Order level ID Megaloptera (Dobson flies and Alderflies)
^robust animal, distinctive, abdominal projections robust (see image), found in cobbly rivers
^slender animal, or with slender abdominal projections (dangly bits), found in pools and wetlands

^Beetle larvae swim actively with all legs; usually with wide flat heads and prominent mandibles; middle of the head sometimes projected forwards like a nose on smaller examples; may be biting and killing other animals in the tray.
^Beetle larvae crawl slowly, or, may propel themselves by longitudinal thrashing of the body.
^Larvae without a pair of tails. Last segment tapers to a point and is fringed with swimming hairs.
^Larvae strong swimmers, constantly moving, obvious tails.
^Strongly flattened, round, slater-like larvae, on rocks.
^Elongate slow moving larvae with hard bodies and short legs; often dark coloured, flowing water.
^Soft bodied larvae, still and flowing water.
^Flattened, cockroach-like larvae with simple bodies and long antennae. Yellow, brown to black.
^Larvae with short antennae, not obviously flattened.
^Small to tiny and often comma shaped.
^Larger more elongate larvae shiny, water repellent skin. Sometimes stuck in water surface tension.
^Elongate, slender larvae with feathery lateral gills and terminal anal claws (see picture); head dark, body pale.
^Robust larvae, without feathery gills but may have long lateral filaments; large head with prominent mandibles.
^Large beetle larvae (up to 50mm). Dark head that is angled upwards.
^with compound eyes (like a mirror ball upclose) and wing buds (except on very young animals)
^simple eyes (several dots), never with wing pads
^Large nymphs up to 40mm usually bright green, orange or blue. Animals have gills along the side of the abdomen.
^Smaller nymphs, less flamboyantly coloured, with gills on the tip of the abdomen or with no visible gills.
^Nymphs with two long tails. (These could be broken leaving only ‘stumps’). Gills either absent or look like a tuft or pom-pom at the end of the abdomen.
^Nymphs with short tails, shorter than half the length of the abdomen. Only 3 or 5 gills, which are similar in length and thickness to the tails.
^External gills form tuft at the tip of the abdomen earning them the common name of 'fluffy bums'. Often wag their abdomen to oxygenate the gills.
^Smaller nymphs with no gills on the tip of the abdomen. May also wag, but don't have fluffy gills.
^Smaller nymphs, brown or black with a single row or ridge of triangular projections along their back.
^Large, sprawling nymphs with hairy legs, hairs dark and conspicuous. Often with high contrast patterns
^Large, sprawling nymphs, hairs pale if present. Blond, never darkly patterned.
^Nymphs with a double row of spines along their backs.
^Nymphs without a double row of spines.
^tails flattened, leaf-like or broad, jaw large and folded away under head
^Nymphs with gills along the side of the abdomen.
^Nymphs with gill covers over part of the abdomen; gill covers can look like wing buds but are always behind the last pair of legs.
^Robust dark brown nymphs with alternating spiny V-shaped gills and smaller feathery gills. Move with a distinct rocking horse motion. Large thorax giving a hunched appearance.
^Large nymphs with helmet-like heads and prominent eyes; two different types of gill which are flicked in sync; crawl slowly but can swim rapidly.
^Not as above head not helmet like, upper and lower gills similar.
^Nymphs usually run rather than swim, but can 'dolphin' clumsily if disturbed. Conspicuously flattened nymphs, head square. Legs sprawling with wide, flat femurs.
^Nymphs are fast swimmers, but swim in bursts like tiny fish. Nymphs not flattened or sprawling, head bullet shaped. Tails fringed with hairs.
^Gills fluffy, each one ending in many fingers making them look like tinsel.
^Large nymphs up to 17mm. Antennae shorter than head. Rare.
^Small nymphs less than 10mm. Antennae longer than head. Common.
^Very small <5mm grey brown nymphs with a fuzzy silt covered appearance. Slow moving but may swim lazily. Flat gill covers large, meeting along the midline like a mini skirt.
^Larger nymphs with a camouflage pattern and eyes which may appear to shine in bright light. Rarely crawl but swim rapidly. Gill covers small, elliptical, not meeting in the middle.
^with suction cups on either end of the body
^with hard mouthparts (these can be inside the head and difficult to see)
^Order level ID Diptera (maggots or true fly larvae)
^Maggots break the surface of the water to breathe; their bodies are buoyant in deeper water (floaters).
^Maggots don't need contact with the water surface, bodies are not buoyant in deeper water, may still be active and swim past the surface (sinkers).
^Animal has obviously sclerotised (armoured or hardened) body plates, either the whole body or bands on all segments.
^Animal mostly soft bodied, although it may have sclerotised plates on its head and abdomen.
^All of body sclerotised (darkened and toughened skin), animal can grow to 20mm.
^Only bands of the upper surface of the body are sclerotised, smaller than 6mm.
^Animals with obviously sclerotised (dark) head capsule and final segments.
^Animal restricted to the water surface, bent 'U' posture at rest, final segments usually out of the water so they distort the surface.
^Often dive when disturbed, leaving the surface quite readily, move in a rapid tumbling or wriggling motion.
^Animal with a distinctive elongate tail (a snorkel).
^Animal with very few characteristics of note, maggot-like in appearance.
^Bleffs (very distinctive, see picture), only found in fast flowing water.
^Animal with a head capsule; long, thin, worm-like or leech-like body form and movement.
^Animal without a head capsule; traditionally maggot-like in body form and movement.

^Animal moves like a leech, rarely losing hold of the substrate, abdomen broadly swollen giving a 'chicken drumstick' appearance, expandable antennae modified to form broad 'antlers' for filter feeding; typical of fast flowing waters with solid surfaces.
^Animal moves by coiling and uncoiling, or by rapid undulations. Unattached to the substrate; abdomen may be swollen but only the very end; antennae small and simple if present.
^Animal looks like a swimming eyelash, with stiff, snake-like movements.
^Head capsule obvious, small prolegs at both ends of the animal, rarely longer than 7mm.
^Head capsule retractable, no pro-legs, sometimes with a set of hairy, feathered or fleshy appendages at the posterior end, may be covered in downy hairs, often longer than 5mm.
^Appendages along both sides of the animal (see picture).
^Animal without appendages or only present on the final segments of the animal.

flat_snails.#: movement: "Slow, will retract into shell and drop off vegetation, so it is sometimes worth panning through sand at the end of a live pick to see if you can find them."

potamopyrgus_antipodarum.#: habitat: "In very large numbers in impacted, high nutrient streams. INTRODUCED SPECIES (from New Zealand)"
confusedWith: "Some snails from the same family in healthy streams, see Genus Beddomeia, family Hydrobiidae, at the end of this section."
description: "The shells of these snails vary considerably.  Some are smooth, while others develop pegs or teeth on the edges of the whorls."

physa_acuta.#: habitat: "Flowing water or wetlands widespread. INTRODUCED SPECIES (from the USA)"
confusedWith: "Planorbids can look very similar, but Physa acuta has a mottled mantle that is usually visible through the shell."

planorbids.#: habitat: "Wetlands / rivers with slow water and lots of water plants. Common and diverse."

confusedWith: "Algae covered shells might be difficult to distinguish from Physa acuta. These Snails are fairly diverse, so they might not look exactly the same as those in the picture; some have ornamentation or flattened tops."

lymnaeidae.#: confusedWith: "Nothing, most other dextral snails are much smaller. Lymnaeids can be mottled but they are dextral so they cannot be confused with Physa acuta."

ancylidae.#: habitat: "Both still and flowing waters, on rocks or vegetation. Common."
movement: "Very slow. Can stick to the sorting tray, so they are worth checking for after a live-pick once you have tipped the rest of the sample out."
confusedWith: "Nothing, but they can be very small and the shell can be transparent so they are sometimes hard to see."

hyriidae.#: habitat: "Often found in groups, almost completely dug into the sandy bottom of slow flowing rivers."

sphaeriidae_and_corbiculidae.#: habitat: "Often found in groups, almost completely dug into the sandy bottom of slow flowing rivers.Flowing and still waters, usually amongst sand or finer sediments. Can be found in large numbers. Common."
confusedWith: "Small Hyriidae, but Hyriidae are usually asymmetrical and much larger."

parastacidae.#: habitat: "Crayfish in rivers (with spines) yabbies in wetlands/pools (more leathery)."
movement: "walking, with sudden flips when disturbed. "

confusedWith: "n            Nothing, very distinctive. We have left crayfish and yabbies grouped togethern            because they mostly turn up as juveniles in samples and are difficult to separate when young.n          "

macrobrachium.#: habitat: "Lowland rivers on wood or amongst water weeds."
confusedWith: "Atyidae, but pincers on second leg very distinctive when fully grown."

atyidae.#: habitat: "slow moving parts of rivers near wood and weeds. Common and often abundant."
movement: "Fast, with lots of flipping when in a tray."
confusedWith: "Palaemonidae, but front 2 pairs of Atyidae legs are shorter and usually with brushes."

hymenosomatidae.#: commonName: "five cent crab, false spider crab"
habitat: "Lakes, and the sluggish, estuarine ends of rivers."

amphipoda.#: habitat: "Wetlands. Weeds in slower parts of rivers, or leaf packs in faster rivers. Very Common."
movement: "Bursts of movement, usually on their sides."

phreatoicidae.#: habitat: "Wetlands. Rivers. Usually not common but can occur in large numbers."
confusedWith: " Amphipods, but they are far more robust looking and slow moving."

janiridae.#: confusedWith: "If terrestrial slaters fall in they look similar. Can be extremely small."

anostraca.#: movement: "Constant with pulsing rows of legs."
confusedWith: "Nothing, but can be difficult to definitively separate natives from pest species."

description: "n          Native fairy shrimp (left) tend to be larger (up to 25mm) and paler coloured, while the introduced sea monkeys (right) tend to be smaller (up to 10mm) and pink or orange. Native fairy shrimp can live in fresh or salty waters, while sea monkeys prefer salty watersn        "

notostraca.#: confusedWith: "Nothing in wetlands ...but they do look like horseshoe crabs."

conchostraca.#: habitat: "Temporary Wetlands. Common but cryptic and short lived."
movement: "Busy, haphazard then they drop from the water column."
confusedWith: "Some pea shells, but legs are obvious on live animals."

acarina.#: movement: "Very active swimmers, legs move very fast."

pisauridae_and_lycosidae.#: movement: "Running rapidly on the surface, then crawling underwater leaving a silvery layer of air trapped against the body."
confusedWith: "Terrestrial spiders, which cannot do the air layer trick or run on water as effectively."

gyrinidae_adult.#: habitat: "Wetlands and river edges, common and conspicuous."
movement: "Fast, and mainly on the surface in circular patterns, although they will dive underwater if threatened."
confusedWith: "Nothing, movement and appearance are both very distinctive."

hygrobia_adult.#: confusedWith: "Nothing, the oddly lumpy appearance is distinctive. Most will screech while being collected."

hydrophilidae_adult.#: habitat: "Wetlands and river edges. Common and abundant."
description: "very variable size, can be as small as 2mm"

carabhydrus.#: confusedWith: "Nothing, strong constriction of the pronotum is distinctive."

australphilus.#: confusedWith: "Nothing, strong colour pattern and tapered body are distinctive."

little_diving_beetles.#: habitat: "Wetlands and slow moving water in rivers. "
movement: "Strong swimmer using hind legs, rarely stops moving. "
confusedWith: "Nothing, most of the medium beetles should be noticeably larger."

mixed_diving_beetles.#: habitat: "Wetlands and slow moving water in rivers. "
confusedWith: "Anything with a pattern in this size class is considered the same."

stealth_diving_beetles.#: movement: "Some of these may move quite slowly for diving beetles."
confusedWith: "Nothing, black. May sometimes have a light coloured spot on the head."

eretes.#: habitat: "Wetlands and slow moving water in rivers. "
confusedWith: "Rhantus, but colour patterns are different, note Eretes has a pale coloured underside."

rhantus.#: habitat: "Wetlands and slow moving water in rivers. "

hyderodes.#: confusedWith: "Large hydrophilid beetles, but hydrophilids are flat underneath."

spencerhydrus.#: confusedWith: "Onychohydrus, but Onychohydrus is usually larger and pale underneath. (Photo is actually Onychohydrus ...but they are very, very similar)."

onychohydrus.#: confusedWith: "Spencerhydrus, but Spencerhydrus is smaller and dark/black underneath."

curculionidae.#: confusedWith: "Nothing, it has a distinctive nose."

elmidae_adult.#: habitat: "Cool flowing waters (riffles), often found on wood, common but hard to see. "
movement: "Hangs in the water or clings to detritus, slow."
confusedWith: "Nothing, very few beetles are as slow or with such impressive claws. Often overlooked due to size."

hydraenidae_and_hydrochidae.#: habitat: "Wetlands, wet rock surfaces near waterfalls. Uncommon, but can be abundant. Hydraenids in wetlands can walk on the water undersurface. "

helochares.#: movement: "Slow, sometimes walk on the water undersurface."
confusedWith: "Other hydrophilids, but Helochares does not swim."

veliidae_mesoveliidae_and_hebridae.#: habitat: "Wetlands and river edges. Very common."
movement: "Fast, look a bit like they have been sped up."

confusedWith: "Nothing. If they are in large numbers and are dark or black they are probably Veliidae (two lower photos). Pale individuals are likely to be Mesoveliidae (top photo). Hebridae are relatively rare."

hydrometridae.#: habitat: "Wetlands, still water. Uncommon, but very cool."

gelastocoridae.#: movement: "Slow, ponderous, but surprisingly can jump."

ranatra.#: movement: "Swims awkwardly or not at all (sit-and-wait predator)."

laccotrephes.#: habitat: "Wetlands. Still water. Uncommon but spectacular."
movement: "Slow or not at all (sit-and-wait predator)."

pleidae.#: habitat: "Wetlands and river edges. Common but cryptic."

enithares.#: habitat: "Wetlands and slow river sections. Still water, very common."
movement: "In bursts. Still when it is at the surface re-filling air supplies."

anisops.#: habitat: "Wetlands and slow river sections. Still water, very common"
movement: "Deliberate strokes of swimming legs, sometimes still, mid-water. Less relaxed in an ice cube tray."

naucoris.#: habitat: "Wetlands and weedy river edges. Common."

diaprepocoris_barycephala.#: habitat: "Wetlands and slow river sections. Slow moving water. "

sigara.#: habitat: "Wetlands and slow river sections. Slow moving water. Common."

micronecta.#: habitat: "Wetlands and slow river sections. Very very common. Often found in large numbers (see soup picture)."

agraptocorixa.#: habitat: "Wetlands and slow river sections. Slow moving water. Common."

hydroptilidae.#: habitat: "All water bodies, cases vary accordingly."
movement: "Slow moving, don't move at all immediately after being disturbed...will need 10-15 minutes to get over shock."

atriplectides.#: habitat: "Lakes and rivers amongst deposits of sand and debris where it finds carrion. Uncommon, but very cool."
confusedWith: "Nothing, very distinctive. Notice the way the hind legs are held out of the way when moving, and mainly get used to latch onto food."

agapetus.#: habitat: "Cool flowing waters, forest streams, riffles. Uncommon, but abundant when they do occur."
confusedWith: "Coarser case might look like Tasimiidae, but glossosomatids don't have tapered/triangular cases."

helicopsyche.#: habitat: "Cool flowing water, forest streams, riffles. Rare, but can be abundant."

tasimiidae.#: habitat: "Small mountain streams, amongst coarse, stable substrate."
confusedWith: "Glossosomatidae. Tasimiids have bulgy eyes if you can get close enough to look at their heads and coarser, triangular cases."

philorheithridae.#: habitat: "Cold flowing water, edges, riffles. Common but sparse (as are most predators). "
confusedWith: "Young leptocerids have a tubular sand case, but they have much longer hind legs."

attack_caddis_lowlander.#: habitat: "Cold flowing water, edges, riffles. Common but sparse (as are most predators). "
confusedWith: "Young leptocerids have a tubular sand case, but they have much longer hind legs."

anisocentropus.#: habitat: "Slow flowing water, backwaters, edges, in leaf packs. Uncommon. "

caenota_plicata.#: habitat: "Slow flowing water, backwaters, edges, in leaf packs. Uncommon."

lectrides_varians.#: habitat: "Wetlands, lakes and pools in rivers. Common and often abundant."
confusedWith: "Case is superficially similar to the shingle caddis, but Lectrides' cases are messy and lack the neat double row of leaf plates."

conoesucidae_calocidae_and_helicophidae.#: confusedWith: "Young leptocerids; the distinction between long and short hind legs is not as great with juveniles."

triplectides.#: habitat: "Wetlands, lakes, slow flowing sections in rivers. Common and often abundant."
confusedWith: "All stick cases are from the Genus Triplectides, but not all Triplectides have stick cases."

log_cabin_caddis.#: movement: "Hovers with flailing arms, like a helicopter."

symphitoneuria.#: movement: "Crawls on veg, when dislodged, the case falls like a dart with the heavy end first (the sandy bit)."

notalina.#: habitat: "Wetlands, lakes and pools in rivers. Common and often abundant."
confusedWith: "Nothing, case and movement are distinctive."

description: "Notalina are special for the way they move. They thrash their thorax, head and legs back and forth to move through the water. This exhausting movement earns them the name head banger caddis. They always have slender cases. Cases can sometimes be made of spirally arrangedn              bits of vegetation"

leptocerids.#: habitat: "Wetlands, lakes, slow flowing sections in rivers. Common and often abundant."
confusedWith: "Double check you haven't got Triplectides or one of the other distinctive caddises from this group."

hydropsychidae.#: movement: "Slow moving, sometimes thrashes in open water. Will undulate the abdomen to aerate their gills."
confusedWith: "Nothing, very distinctive once you have noticed the 'hairy chest' of gills on the abdomen."

ecnomus.#: habitat: "Still and flowing water, edges. Common."

confusedWith: "Some hunter caddis have a similar head pattern. They are relatively fast moving and 'quest' with their front legs for prey, while ecnomids are less active, and have all three leg-bearing segments sclerotised (hardened). "

hydrobiosidae.#: habitat: "Cool flowing water, riffles, and forest streams. Common."
movement: "Fast moving, hunt with front legs in front of their body on the off-chance they might hit prey."

philopotamidae_polycentropodidae_and_ecn.#: habitat: "Cool flowing water, riffles, edges, forest streams. Rare."

lepidoptera.#: habitat: "Slow moving or still water in amongst aquatic vegetation."
confusedWith: "Beetle larvae or uncased caddis larvae, but caterpillars have rows of extra grasping organs along their abdomen."

megapodagrionidae.#: habitat: "Occurs in slow flowing waters, at the edges of streams, in bogs and seepages. Uncommon."
confusedWith: "Nothing, unless it has lost its gills."

synlestidae.#: habitat: "At the edge of streams amongst tree roots and vegetation. Rare."
confusedWith: "Nothing, unless it has lost its gills."

isostictidae.#: habitat: "At the edge of streams amongst tree roots and vegetation. Rare."
confusedWith: "Will look almost exactly like a synlestid (stripy legs and all), but with longer, obviously divided gills."

diphlebiidae.#: habitat: "Wetlands, or slow moving water in rivers."
movement: "Slow, but may swim with a sideways undulating motion if disturbed."
confusedWith: "Nothing, unless it has lost its gills."

lestidae_and_coenagrionidae.#: habitat: "Wetlands, or slow moving water in rivers. Very common and sometimes abundant."
movement: "Slow, but may swim with a rapid sideways undulating motion if disturbed."
confusedWith: "Nothing, unless it has lost its gills."

spider_mud_eye.#: habitat: "Slow flowing waters, among detritus and silt."
movement: "Slow and careful, but can use a bum jet if disturbed."

gomphidae.#: habitat: "Rivers, among detritus and silt, and sometimes wetlands or lakes."
movement: "Slow and careful, but can use a bum jet if disturbed."
confusedWith: "Nothing so long as you get a good look at the antennae. These are obvious even on juveniles."

telephlebiidae.#: movement: "Slow and careful, but can use a bum jet if disturbed."
confusedWith: "Note the 'Humbug' patterned juvenile is similar to Aeshnidae"

aeshnidae.#: habitat: "Wetlands, slow rivers or lakes. Common."
movement: "Slow and careful, but can use a bum jet if disturbed."

neuroptera.#: movement: "Very fast moving (underwater)or slow moving (semi terrestrial)"
confusedWith: "Beetle larvae, but lacewings often have a distinct neck and their jaws are longer and straighter."

corydalidae.#: confusedWith: "Gyrinid and Hydrophilid beetle larvae, which are much smaller and are not found in fast flowing rivers."

taper_tailed_tiger_larvae.#: confusedWith: "Some two-tailed tigers will have smallish tails, so you might need to check with a hand lens."

two_tailed_tiger_larvae.#: confusedWith: "See taper-tailed tigers.Small individuals might key out as swimming water tigers, but swimming water tigers usually have better developed tails."

nosey_tiger_larvae.#: habitat: "Wetlands and river edges. Very common."
confusedWith: "BEWARE: These animals have a pair of tails, or 2 tails and a siphon, so can potentially end up ID'd as stoneflies or mayflies."

swimming_water_tiger_larvae.#: confusedWith: "Small individuals from the two-tailed tigers will unavoidably key out as swimming water tigers."

crawling_water_tiger_larvae.#: confusedWith: "Nothing, all the other dytiscid larvae will be fast moving."

sclerocyphon.#: confusedWith: "Trilobites, but they have been extinct since the Carboniferous (280,000,000 years ago), and are marine."

scirtidae.#: habitat: "Flowing water, wetlands, river edges. Fairly common."
confusedWith: "Nothing, the flattened shape and long antennae are good characters."

elmidae_larvae.#: habitat: "Cool flowing water. Very common. Often found on wood."
movement: "Slow or still, very difficult to see, some species are very small and camouflaged.....good luck."

byrrocryptus.#: movement: "Slow, often holding onto vegetation, or trapped in surface tension."

gyrinidae_larvae.#: movement: "Fast, mix of swimming with legs and undulating the abdomen."
confusedWith: "Nothing, feathery projections are distinctive, may need a hand lens to see these."

berosus.#: confusedWith: "Gyrinid larvae, but the lateral filaments on Berosus lack feathering, and Berosus is rarely as slender."

hydrophilus.#: movement: "Slow crawl or swimming with all legs."
confusedWith: "Nothing. Nothing else gets this big."

water_scavenger_beetle_larvae.#: confusedWith: "Juvenile ugly bobs (Hydrophilus) are difficult to tell apart, but they have darker heads that are angled/kinked up. For water scavenger beetle larvae the head is in line with the rest of the body."

eustheniidae.#: habitat: "Upland streams, more often in alpine and sub-alpine areas."
movement: "Deliberate, may try and crawl out of picking tray."

riekoperla.#: confusedWith: "Other gripops, you will need to look at these animals from the side to make sure you see the projections."

hairy_sprawler.#: movement: "Slow, sometimes flex side to side while unattached."
confusedWith: "Other gripops can be similar. With a white background you can be more confident that you haven't missed the dark, extremely hairy legs."

illiesoperla.#: movement: "Slow, sometimes flex side to side while unattached."

confusedWith: "Hairy sprawlers can appear similar. However, with a white background and a hand lens, you can be more confident that you haven't just missed the hairy legs. Illiesoperla can have hairs on its legs, but never long dark ones, and often has light purple gills. Sometimes beigen              or brown rather than blond."

gripops_or_fluffy_bums.#: confusedWith: "This is a diverse group of leftovers, check carefully for projections and hairy legs before using this name."

notonemouridae.#: habitat: "Occurs in small upland streams and in small lowland streams. Sometimes found in wetlands."
confusedWith: "Gripops that have retracted their gill tufts will key out here. Look closely with a hand lens, also check for tail wagging, a characteristically gripop behaviour."
description: "Notice the 'alert' posture. Inset photo shows the abdomen without gills."

acruroperla_atra.#: habitat: "Often associated with submerged wood in upland streams."
confusedWith: "Nothing, one of the snazziest stonefly nymphs you will see."

austroperlids.#: habitat: "Cool upland forested streams, often amongst bark and leaf litter."
confusedWith: "Nothing, the short tails and long abdomen are good characters."

coloburiscoides.#: habitat: "Cool upland streams. Common and abundant in healthy boulder streams."
confusedWith: "Nothing, very distinctive in robustness and movement. Look for spiky V shaped gills for confirmation."

mirawara.#: habitat: "Fast flowing cool cobbly streams. Rare."
movement: "Fast and searching for prey. Regularly 'shuffles' gills."
confusedWith: "Nothing, very distinctive head shape and size."

atalophlebia.#: habitat: "Slower flowing waters, sometimes wetlands. Very common."
movement: "Can sometimes 'dolphin' when disturbed, but otherwise walks."
confusedWith: "Other leptophlebs, but the banded legs and fluffy gills are VERY distinctive."

leptophlebs.#: movement: "Scurry, then stay still. A bit like a huntsman spider, can sometimes 'dolphin' when disturbed."

siphlonuridae.#: habitat: "Cool, fish free alpine streams and lakes. Very rare. "
movement: "Walks slowly, infrequent bursts of movement. "
confusedWith: "Baetids, but baetids are generally smaller, and have long antennae."

baetidae.#: movement: "Bursts of movement like a tiny fish."

caenidae.#: habitat: "Still and slow moving waters with silty areas. Common. "
confusedWith: "Nothing, very distinctive once you have seen the square gill covers."

tasmanophlebia.#: habitat: "Cool flowing water, edges, backwaters, forest streams. Uncommon."
confusedWith: "baetids if you don't see the gill covers."

stratiomyidae.#: habitat: "Wetlands, still water, salt lakes. Common."
movement: "Slow moving almost still but floating."
confusedWith: "Nothing, very distinctive amount of sclerotisation and usually suspended from surface by its rear end."

psychodidae.#: confusedWith: "Nothing, very distinctive once you have found them. Might look stripy like some elmid beetle larvae."

dixidae.#: habitat: "Wetlands, still water, the edges of farm dams. Uncommon."
movement: "Bend and unbend just under water surface."
confusedWith: "Nothing, the large plate that punctures the surface (like an air anchor) and the movement are unique."

culicidae.#: habitat: "Wetlands, still water, even buckets left out for too long. Common."
confusedWith: "Nothing, very distinctive and well known to most people."

ephydridae_and_sciomyzidae.#: habitat: "Wetlands, still water, Ephydrids in salty lakes. Widespread."
confusedWith: "Most things maggoty, the short body and welts are good clues. This group NEVER has tassels."

blephariceridae.#: habitat: "Fast flowing streams with stable boulders, lives in the fastest bits."

simuliidae.#: habitat: "Fast flowing waters. Common and abundant."
confusedWith: "Nothing, other than chicken drumsticks. Very distinctive."

Chironomus.#: movement: ": Coil and uncoil quickly in a figure of eight, sometimes thrashing or using prolegs to drag themselves along the ground."

ceratopogonidae.#: habitat: "Wetlands, still water, river edges. Common."
movement: "Like a stiff snake, or a swimming eyelash, very distinctive."
confusedWith: "Nothing, very distinctive movement, and nothing else has the pointy head."

chironomid.#: movement: ": Coil and uncoil quickly in a figure of eight, sometimes thrashing or using prolegs to drag themselves along the ground."
confusedWith: "Nothing, very distinctive but quite variable. "

tipulidae.#: habitat: "All habitats. Common but not abundant."
movement: "Slow moving burrowing with twists, or with expansion and contraction."
confusedWith: "Nothing, very distinctive. Some have distinctive, swollen, rear ends (photo left) and others complicated breathing appendages (photo right)."

athericidae.#: confusedWith: "Nothing, very distinctive once you have definitely seen the side projections."

oligochaeta.#: movement: "Like an earthworm. Smaller worms may swim by wriggling."
confusedWith: "Leeches, but worms have no suckers."

hirudinea.#: movement: "Characteristic looping motion, elongation and contraction of body."
confusedWith: "Worms or flatworms, neither of which have suckers."

turbellaria.#: confusedWith: "Leeches, but flatworms have no suckers and move differently."

nematoda.#: habitat: "Rivers, wetlands, all habitats in sediment."
confusedWith: "Gordian worms, which are much larger."

nematomorpha.#: movement: "Very slow and deliberate coiling and uncoiling."

plecoptera.#: movement: "Variable, but usually slow walk or side to side lizard-like gate"
description: "Stoneflies are some of the most sensitive waterbugs to water quality."

ephemeroptera.#: movement: "Variable, some swim rapidly like little fish, others walk or thrash"
confusedWith: "Mayflies with damaged tails might look like stoneflies (2 tails)."
description: "Mayflies are some of the most sensitive waterbugs to water quality."

megaloptera.#: confusedWith: "Gyrinid and Hydrophilid beetle larvae, which are much smaller and are not found in fast flowing rivers."

anaspidacea.#: movement: "Slow deliberate, many-legged crawl. Can flip like a shrimp if disturbed."
confusedWith: "shrimp with damaged legs appear similar"
description: "Anaspides is mainly found in mountainous parts of Tasmania, a smaller (to 20mm), lowland anaspid called Koonunga can be found in groundwater fed streams and wetlands."

coleoptera.#: confusedWith: "Bugs can appear similar to adult beetles , but are less rounded dorsally, and have asymetrically folded wings."
description: "An extremely diverse group that occur both as larvae and adults in fresh waters"

zygoptera.#: habitat: "Wetlands, or slow moving water in rivers. Common and sometimes abundant."
movement: "Slow, but may swim with a rapid sideways undulating motion if disturbed."
confusedWith: "Nothing, unless it has lost its gills."
description: "Slender sit and wait predators wth prominant terminal gills"

epiproctophora.#: movement: "Slow and careful, but can use a bum jet if disturbed."

bivalvia.#: habitat: "Often found in groups, almost completely dug into the sandy bottom of slow flowing rivers."

isopoda.#: confusedWith: " Amphipods, but they are far more robust looking and slow moving."

hemiptera.#: habitat: "Wetlands and slow river sections. Still water, very common."
confusedWith: "Beetles, but beetles have their wings separated symetrically."

gastropoda.#: description: "To quote T. Sloane, booger with a crash helmet."

trichoptera.#: movement: "usually fairly quick unless playing possum."
description: "The Trichoptera are considered sensitive to pollution."

trichoptera_free_living.#: movement: "usually fairly quick unless playing possum."
confusedWith: "Sometimes glossosomatids will and other cased caddis will fall out of their cases, you can differentiate them by their short anal prolegs."

trichoptera_cased.#: movement: "usually fairly quick unless playing possum."

sialidae.#: confusedWith: "Gyrinid and Hydrophilid beetle larvae, which are slightly smaller and don't end in a single long filament."

australatya.#: habitat: "fast moving parts of rivers. Common and often abundant."
movement: "Fast, with lots of flipping when in a tray."
confusedWith: "Palaemonidae and other Atyidae, but all the legs are short and the stripes are prominent ."

sphaeromatidae.#: habitat: "Lower reaches river edges, especially near wood.  Often areas with tidal influence"
confusedWith: "If terrestrial slaters fall in they look similar. Can be extremely small."

leptoperla.#: movement: "Slow, sometimes flex side to side while unattached."

crypturoperla_paradoxa.#: movement: "Slow, sometimes flex side to side while unattached."
confusedWith: "Acruroperla atra looks sim ilar but is from the mainland."
